But its final report has found those allegations were "incorrect" and "without any rational basis".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The board of inquiry into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann over the alleged rape of Brittany Higgins was sparked by allegations made by ACT Director of Public Prosecutions Shane Drumgold against police. But its final report has found those allegations were "incorrect" and "without any rational basis". You can read more about this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bruce Lehrmann inquiry report heavily criticises man who prosecuted the case of 'knowingly lying' to Chief Justice

featuredLink.title: Bruce Lehrmann inquiry report heavily criticises man who prosecuted the case of 'knowingly lying' to Chief Justice

children.content: The board of inquiry into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann over the alleged rape of Brittany Higgins was sparked by allegations made by ACT
Director of Public Prosecutions Shane Drumgold against police.
But its final report has found those allegations were "incorrect" and "without any rational basis".
You can read more about this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ADF has confirmed unidentified human remains have been found in the search for the MRH-90 helicopter crash that claimed four lives during a military exercise last week. Australian Defence Force Chief of Joint Operations Lieutenant General Greg Bilton says a remotely operated underwater vehicle located a further debris field including parts of the cockpit. "The debris field is consistent with a catastrophic, high impact," he says. "Sadly I can confirm unidentified human remains have also been observed in this location by the remote operated underwater vehicle." They were found 40 metres below the surface. "Due to the nature of the debris field positive identified of the remains is unlikely to occur until we recover more of the wreckage," he said. You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Human remains and cockpit debris found in search for downed MRH-90 helicopter

featuredLink.title: Human remains found near Taipan helicopter wreckage

children.content: The ADF has confirmed unidentified human remains have been found in the search for the MRH-90 helicopter crash that claimed four lives during a military exercise last week.
Australian Defence Force Chief of Joint Operations Lieutenant General Greg Bilton says a remotely operated underwater vehicle located a further debris field including parts of the cockpit.
"The debris field is consistent with a catastrophic, high impact," he says.
"Sadly I can confirm unidentified human remains have also been observed in this location by the remote operated underwater vehicle."
They were found 40 metres below the surface.
"Due to the nature of the debris field positive identified of the remains is unlikely to occur until we recover more of the wreckage," he said.
You can read more on this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An additional 43 charges have been laid against a bus driver who was at the wheel of a coach that crashed in the Hunter Valley, killing 10 people. The bus carrying wedding guests rolled on a roundabout near the Hunter Expressway at Greta in June. The new charges include nine offences each of alleged dangerous and negligent driving occasioning grievous bodily harm. There are also 25 new charges of causing bodily harm by misconduct. You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hunter Valley wedding bus crash driver faces 43 additional charges

featuredLink.title: Hunter Valley bus crash driver to face 43 additional charges

children.content: An additional 43 charges have been laid against a bus driver who was at the wheel of a coach that
crashed in the Hunter Valley, killing 10 people.
The bus carrying wedding guests rolled on a roundabout near the Hunter Expressway at Greta in June.
The new charges include nine offences each of alleged dangerous and negligent driving occasioning grievous bodily harm.
There are also 25 new charges of causing bodily harm by misconduct.
You can read more on this story here:

title.children: Retail sales figures help explain RBA rate hike pause

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Those underwhelming retail figures my colleague Michael Janda has been posting about have seen the Australian dollar take another hit. At midday it was about 65.45 US cents, but it's now about 65.31 US cents. It also lost more than a per cent last night. A lot of it has to do with what the market thinks about the RBA's interest rate decision (and future moves or otherwise). Across the ditch in New Zealand, their dollar is also lower against the greenback.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dollar down

children.content: Those underwhelming retail figures my colleague
Michael Janda
has been posting about have seen the Australian dollar take another hit.
At midday it was about 65.45 US cents, but it's now about 65.31 US cents.
It also lost more than a per cent last night.
A lot of it has to do with what the market thinks about the RBA's interest rate decision (and future moves or otherwise).
Across the ditch in New Zealand, their dollar is also lower against the greenback.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Downer EDI announced it expects to report a statutory net loss after tax of about $386 million for the 2023 financial year. The company will write off almost $550 million when it reports its full-year results to the market next week. The impairment comes from increased debt costs and "tightening market conditions" for its cleaning and maintenance business Spotless, which caters to the defence sector. Downer EDI lowered its forecasts after lawsuits were filed alleging breaches of disclosures regarding a maintenance contract and the Sydney-based company revealed accounting irregularities in December. "Downer is undergoing a period of significant and necessary organisational change. Against this backdrop, we have delivered underlying earnings in line with what was previously communicated," CEO Peter Tompkins said in a statement. Downer EDI posted its biggest single-day loss in six months, falling nearly 6 per cent, but has recovered some of that fall in mid-afternoon trade to sit a bit over 2 per cent below yesterday's closing figure.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Downer EDI a downer on the market today

children.content: Downer EDI
announced it expects to report a
statutory net loss
after tax of about
$386 million
for the 2023 financial year.
The company will
write off almost $550 million
when it reports its full-year results to the market next week.
The impairment comes from increased debt costs and "tightening market conditions" for its cleaning and maintenance business Spotless, which caters to the defence sector.

Downer EDI lowered its forecasts after lawsuits were filed alleging breaches of disclosures regarding a maintenance contract and the Sydney-based company revealed accounting irregularities in December.

"Downer is undergoing a period of significant and necessary organisational change. Against this backdrop, we have delivered underlying earnings in line with what was previously communicated," CEO Peter Tompkins said in a statement.
Downer EDI posted its
biggest single-day loss in six months
, falling nearly 6 per cent, but has recovered some of that fall in mid-afternoon trade to sit a bit over 2 per cent below yesterday's closing figure.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's a bit of movement on the ASX today among some companies in the battery metals space. Australian Strategic Materials (ASM), which owns deposits in New South Wales (though is yet to mine anything and sources its rare earths ore from other miners in Asia), has signed a deal with USA Rare Earth. ASM owns a rare earths processing plant in South Korea — that arm of the business has signed a five-year deal with the US company to supply neodymium iron boron alloy from 2024. Neodymium is used to make permanent magnets for things like medical imaging machines, engines and communications technology. It's shares are up more than 5 per cent. Liontown Resources, which mines lithium (another critical component in batteries) in the Goldfields region of WA, announced today it will export lithium direct shipping ore (DSO) (the least refined product) before it exports its first concentrate (ore that's been partly refined) as way to raise some cash. Liontown has so far stockpiled 70,000 tonnes of DSO and expects to sell up to 300,000 tonnes, likely starting by the end of this calendar year. Liontown's m anaging director and CEO, Tony Ottaviano, said: "Progressing with the production of DSO not only provides early revenue potential, but also enables us to de-risk the project by field testing our ore sorting and logistics solutions on a smaller scale ahead of first concentrate production mid-2024." Liontown shares are up 0.2 per cent .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Battery Metals in demand
